thread.title: ‘Just in time’: Reality of Maitua’s suicide attempt
thread.title_full: ‘Just in time’: Reality of Maitua’s suicide attempt

title: ‘Just in time’: Reality of Maitua’s suicide attempt
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS “HE probably got there just in time.” 
Former NRL bad boy Reni Maitua knows if good mate Willie Tonga had been a minute later, he might not be alive to tell the story. 
It’s well known Tonga saved Maitua’s life in 2013 when he foiled a suicide attempt by his friend and one-time rugby league teammate. 
Maitua tried to take his own life two days after Parramatta’s round 23 loss to Brisbane that season. 
He had broken down in tears while sitting in the Suncorp Stadium sheds and made the decision to suicide. 
He sent text messages to his mother and sister on the night of the attempt, but it was Tonga who made the desperate dash to Maitua’s apartment in the early morning and stopped him. 
Maitua opened up on that fateful night during a one-on-one with On The Couch With Sterlo .

“It was an 18-month period where we (Parramatta) weren’t doing too well as a club and I take a lot of pride as most athletes do in their ability and how they want to play,” Maitua said. 
“Ricky (Stuart) was coming in and I wanted to do the best I could for him — obviously I’d let him down at Cronulla. 
“I trained all through pre-season, I went to Thailand and trained over Christmas because I wanted it so bad. 
“I took on the weight of the team, and we had one of those years where we were unsuccessful again. 
“There were certain things going on in my life outside the game and it was just the perfect storm. 
“Round 23 was the breaking point. I don’t know what it was, but I broke down uncontrollably after the game. 
“That was the weekend I did try to take my own life.” 
But Tonga intervened and saved his friend’s life. Reni Maitua for the Bulldogs. Source: News Corp Australia 
Maitua says he tries not to think about that night too often, but there’s one thing that still burns him. 
“That was a burden that I have to carry, putting my friend through that sort of thing,” Maitua said of Tonga. 
“Putting my family, friend and peers through that kind of thing. But how it effected Willie was what effected me the most. 
“I look back at it now and my job is to make sure that doesn’t happen to anyone else.” 
Maitua is happy to leave the past behind him and look to the future. 
He’s started offering his services to rugby league clubs as a speaker or player adviser, hoping younger players can learn the mistakes he made. 
Maitua was axed by Canterbury in 2008 for his attitude towards training, then in 2009 was served a two-year ban from the NRL after testing positive to illicit drugs. 
It was the Eels who threw him a lifeline when he returned in 2011, and he retired with 174 NRL games to his name. Reni Maitua training with Samoa. Source: News Corp Australia 
He reflects on his career with mixed emotions. 
“I certainly do have regrets. I feel like I underachieved in my career,” Maitua told On The Couch With Sterlo . 
“I never got to put the Blues jersey on, I was only 18th man once and that’s something that every player wants to do, play the pinnacle of league and that’s Origin to me. 
“There’s things that I put my family through, and my friends and teammates, so I definitely have regrets in my life and career. 
“Not many people get the opportunity to play 170 odd first grade games and I’m grateful for that, but I know I could have done a lot better. 
“My job now is to pass on what I know about the game, pass on to players who might be going through the same thing and educate whoever I can on what could be that crossroad in your life.”
